content.title: Thalassemia
content.summary: Thalassemias are inherited hemoglobinopathies characterized by reduced or absent production of one or more globin chains, resulting in ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis. Alpha-thalassemia results from deletion/mutation of α-globin genes, while beta-thalassemia involves mutations in β-globin genes. The hallmark is microcytic hypochromic anemia with normal iron stores.
key_points: Quantitative defect in globin chain production (vs qualitative in sickle cell)
Microcytic hypochromic anemia with NORMAL or elevated iron stores
Alpha-thalassemia: gene deletion model (4 genes, increasing severity)
Target cells, basophilic stippling on peripheral smear
Transfusion dependence in severe forms leads to iron overload
content.statement: Thalassemias are inherited disorders of globin chain synthesis causing microcytic hypochromic anemia from ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis, distinguished from iron deficiency by normal iron stores and elevated RBC count relative to hemoglobin.

explanation.intuition: Think of hemoglobin as a 4-person team that needs equal members. In thalassemia, one type of chain is underproduced, so excess chains precipitate and damage the RBC. It's like building cars when one assembly line (α or β chain) runs slow - the other parts pile up and damage the factory.
explanation.key_insight: The RBC count is often normal or high relative to the hemoglobin level (Mentzer index <13) because the body tries to compensate by making more RBCs, unlike iron deficiency where production is simply limited.
explanation.technical_details: Alpha-thalassemia: 4 α-globin genes (2 per chromosome 16). Deletions cause progressively severe disease (1 gene: silent carrier → 4 genes: hydrops fetalis). Beta-thalassemia: 2 β-globin genes (1 per chromosome 11). Mutations classified as β+ (reduced) or β0 (absent) production.

definitions_glossary.alpha_globin: Globin chain encoded on chromosome 16; 4 genes normally present
definitions_glossary.beta_globin: Globin chain encoded on chromosome 11; 2 genes normally present
definitions_glossary.hemoglobin_A2: Minor adult hemoglobin (α2δ2); elevated in beta-thalassemia trait
definitions_glossary.hemoglobin_H: Abnormal tetramer (β4) seen in 3-gene deletion alpha-thalassemia
definitions_glossary.hemoglobin_Barts: Abnormal tetramer (γ4) seen in alpha-thalassemia at birth
definitions_glossary.ineffective_erythropoiesis: Destruction of RBC precursors in bone marrow before release
definitions_glossary.target_cells: Codocytes seen on smear due to excess membrane relative to hemoglobin
definitions_glossary.basophilic_stippling: Aggregated ribosomes in RBCs indicating abnormal maturation
definitions_glossary.iron_overload: Excessive iron accumulation from transfusions and increased absorption
definitions_glossary.Mentzer_index: MCV/RBC count; <13 suggests thalassemia, >13 suggests iron deficiency

pathophysiology.mechanism: Imbalanced globin chain production leading to precipitation of excess chains

alpha_thalassemia.inheritance: Deletion of 1-4 α-globin genes on chromosome 16
severity_spectrum: Silent carrier (1 gene deleted): Asymptomatic, normal labs
Alpha-thal trait (2 genes deleted): Mild microcytic anemia
HbH disease (3 genes deleted): Moderate hemolytic anemia
Hydrops fetalis (4 genes deleted): Incompatible with life without intrauterine transfusion
alpha_thalassemia.pathology: Excess β chains form β4 tetramers (HbH) which are unstable

beta_thalassemia.inheritance: Point mutations in β-globin genes on chromosome 11
severity_spectrum: Beta-thal minor (β/β+ or β/β0): Mild microcytic anemia, elevated HbA2
Beta-thal intermedia: Moderate anemia, variable transfusion needs
beta_thalassemia.pathology: Excess α chains precipitate, damage RBC membrane

CBC: RBC count often elevated relative to hemoglobin

hemoglobin_electrophoresis.alpha_thal: May be normal (gene testing required); HbH inclusions

differential_diagnosis: Iron deficiency anemia (Mentzer index >13, low ferritin)

thalassemia_major.transfusion: Regular RBC transfusions every 2-4 weeks to maintain Hb 9-10 g/dL
thalassemia_major.splenectomy: For hypersplenism with increased transfusion requirements

supportive: Monitor for endocrine and cardiac complications of iron overload

definition.@value: A group of inherited hemoglobinopathies characterized by decreased or absent production of one or more globin chains, causing microcytic hypochromic anemia from ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis

scopeNote.@value: Quantitative globin chain deficiency; distinguished from qualitative defects like sickle cell disease

learning_objectives: Explain the genetic basis of alpha and beta thalassemia
Distinguish thalassemia from iron deficiency using clinical and laboratory features
Describe the spectrum of severity in alpha and beta thalassemia
Interpret hemoglobin electrophoresis findings in thalassemia
Outline management strategies including transfusion and chelation therapy
clinical_pearls: Mentzer index (MCV/RBC) <13 suggests thalassemia; >13 suggests iron deficiency
HbA2 >3.5% is diagnostic of beta-thalassemia trait
Alpha-thalassemia may have normal hemoglobin electrophoresis - genetic testing needed
Iron overload is the major cause of morbidity in transfusion-dependent patients
Gene therapy offers cure potential for severe beta-thalassemia
Screen Southeast Asian patients for alpha-thalassemia before pregnancy
common_misconceptions: All thalassemias need treatment - thalassemia minor requires only genetic counseling
Iron deficiency and thalassemia are mutually exclusive - they can coexist
Hemoglobin electrophoresis diagnoses alpha-thalassemia - often normal; gene testing required
